newsitem.title: USA: Southern Peru up despite lower copper price.
newsitem.headline: Southern Peru up despite lower copper price.

text.p: Southern Peru Copper Corp net earnings rose to $55.8 million, $0.70 per share, in the first quarter from $49.1 million, $0.61 per share, a year ago despite lower copper prices.
The average price for copper on the London Metal Exchange was $1.10 per pound compared with $1.17.

"The increase in earnings resulted primarily from the company's price protection program, a reduction in our effective tax rate due to a reinvestment incentive in Peru, and a favourable adjustment to provisionally priced sales made in the fourth quarter of 1996," said CEO Charles Preble.

The earnings include pretax gains of $5.6 million on sales of copper put options in 1996 covering the first quarter and Southern Peru has realized $16.7 million before tax from its hedging program from July 1 last year to March 31.
It said that price adjustments for copper shipped in the fourth quarter of last year increased sales by $9.4 million and net earnings by $6.3 million.
Average molyblendum prices were $4.38 per pound against $3.97 and silver was $5.01 an ounce against $5.54 a year ago.
Copper sales were 172,000 pounds, up from 169,000 pounds, while silver slid to 679,000 ounces from 819,000 and molyblendum rose to 2,234,000 pounds from 1,867,000.
Sales rose to $214.8 million from $196.4 million.
The reinvesment tax benefit from Peru has added $5.0 million to net earnings, the company said.
Southern Peru said its $600 million loan facility agreed earlier this year is expected to increase annual copper production by 19 percent, 130 million pounds, by early 1999.
ASARCO Inc owns 54.1 percent of SPCC, Marmon Corp 14.2 percent and Phelps Dodge Corp 13.9 percent. ((-- New York Newsroom 212 859 1902))
